awd_titl_txt: CHS: Small: Blending the Virtual and the Physical: Understanding and Designing Crowd-Based Open Innovation Systems for Physical Products
awd_abstract_narration:
Firms often turn to external contributors to perform vital functions, including "open innovation" scenarios in which firms create challenges or competitions where external crowd workers develop and submit creative ideas.  This project will study a number of open questions around crowd-based open innovation around complex physical products, which pose challenges above and beyond the software and simple design contexts in which open innovation has been studied before.  These include (1) How do external contributors successfully align their contribution to an organization of which they are not a part and propose designs for a physical context to which they do not have easy access?  (2) How do internal employees source, import, and adapt the inputs of external contributors whose assumptions, processes and tools might be entirely different? (3) How can systems and practices be designed to facilitate creative work from external contributors and effective integration into the the firm's processes?  To address these questions the project team will work closely with a firm that uses advanced engineering technologies to develop and manufacture new vehicles, observing the firm and related crowdworker communities during several innovation challenges.  They will also develop material on open innovation for an undergraduate course centered the future of work that both teaches findings from the work and gives students hands-on experience developing a project that incorporates creative crowd input into the group's work.

The team will collect a number of sources of data for each challenge.  From the crowd platform itself, they will collect all of the online discussions from the inception of the challenge to the choice of winning ideas, evaluation of those ideas by both the crowd and the firm, and the subsequent technical work around developing the winning designs.  They will also conduct interviews with online community members, seeking to understand why collaborations form and disband, why some designs are not ultimately submitted to the competition, how community members perceive feedback, and how both winners and non-winners engage with the winning designs.  In parallel, they will observe and interview activity at their partner firm, attending both specific meetings related to the challenges being studied and general weekly meetings (to give an overview of relevant discussions and decisions outside of the challenge itself).  Much of the analysis will involve applying social network and open coding techniques to track interaction patterns and knowledge flows between actors both inside and outside the firm, looking at how these evolve through the course of the challenge.  These, along with grounded theory-based analysis of interviews and observational data, will highlight both key regular patterns (such as the representation and manipulation of non-textual artifacts) and important gaps (such as the need to provide an appropriate but not sensitive or paralyzing level of context) that might benefit from better tool support.

por.por_cntn:
Increasingly, workers are called upon to work across organizational boundaries including contributing as part of online ?communities? outside the bounds of a traditional organization (e.g. ?the crowd?).  We know little about what fuels these creative contributions or how they are integrated into the firm, especially when the objects being produced are physical rather than digital. Our project focused on these questions and the outcomes of our research are threefold. First, we have found that feedback that contains artifacts, and signals co-creation, is associated with more creative submissions in an online community devoted to physical products. We also predicted and found, however, a moderating effect such that being in more ?influential? networks (e.g. connections to more successful projects) reverses these positive effects. Combined with other results, our findings suggest that co-creation behaviors are beneficial, but not if they are coming from high status feedback providers who may have an outsized impact in the community. Using some of the same data, we also found that for high quality submissions, the number of contributors decreased and a small group of involved people became more dominant in providing feedback. Further, we observe that the creators of more successful submissions, while not dominating the discussion, were particularly engaged, especially at later stages. Taken together, these findings provide strong support for the value of active co-creation between creators and feedback providers in these communities. 


In a detailed, multi-year field study of Community Vehicles (a pseudonym), who hosted this online community, we also observed in-house engineering work and examined how and when online co-creation happens during the design process and under what conditions the locus of design shifts between the in-house engineers and the online community. Our data suggest that while opportunity identification resides with the focal firm, concept development, project definition, and project specifications are far more likely to be jointly created at the boundary between the firm and the online community.  We observed significant variance between projects, but every project we observed experienced significant co-creation activities during project definition and specification.  We further explore how the co-creative boundary between the firm and the community was managed and moments when there were breakdowns. This work provides guidance for organizations employing online communities for sourcing innovative design ideas, specifically observing the essential role of engagement with the online community in the early stages of a project for creative outcomes. 


In another paper based on our observations of design activities, we focus on how prototyping creates moments of learning for both engineers and designers. We are examining how engineers learn as they interact around the design of a physical product based on an emerging (and evolving) technology.  Preliminary insights suggest that the kinds of prototypes that are developed and how they are used are contingent on the team?s collective learning approach, the maturity of the underlying technology, and the eventual inputs from the organization?s online community. While prior design theory agrees that prototyping is generally associated with positive design and learning outcomes, we speculate that prototyping can go too far. We show how some prototyping and learning approaches support team-level (and community-level) learning and strategic design outcomes whereas other approaches support only individual level-learning with limited design outcomes.

 

Through this body of work, we have advanced understanding of how work is coordinated in crowd-based open innovation and the factors that lead to higher levels of creative performance, especially when working with physical products and advanced processes and materials (e.g. 3-D printing) that introduce complexity and uncertainty.  More broadly, we provide guidance so that organizations can make more principled decisions regarding the design of systems and processes to sustain higher performance and, especially, more innovativeness when working at the boundary between the firm and open innovation communities.

Modified by: Pamela Hinds
